content.description:
Climb the corner to the first roof.  Climb left out the roof and repeat the entire process for the second large roof.

Locate the two large left facing roofs near the left side of the upper tier.  This route climbs up to and under these two roofs.
Single rack.  Nervous leaders may want to bring up a couple large pieces (2s and 3s).  Build a tree anchor at the top (there may or may not be tat).

Stick clip the first bolt and pull hard moves off the ground. Continue more easily up the face, placing gear in a horizontal and up to the second bolt. Another tricky sequence then more moderate mixed climbing to the anchor.



The face just right of the corner/roofs of Aventure Pédestre.

3 bolts. .4 to .75 cams

climbs.name: Betadine
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Caleb Mazurkiewicz October 2021

content.description:
Start on the right hand side of the face on an easy ramp. Follow the bolts up to a right angling overlap. At the fifth bolt move left onto a crack system that will take you to the top of the wall. Gear: .2, .3, .5 and #3 BD.



Located on the left hand side of Upper Tier. This route is right of Steal Your Face. 

.2, .3, .5 and #3 BD.or equivalent cams. 5 bolts. Tree anchor.

Sustained face climbing with some tough to read moves.

Starts by scrambling up a small mound with a fixed rope just to the left of the obvious ramp of "To Save The Princess".  
Six bolts with quick clips at the top.

Climb up the technical face. Tricky for the grade.



First bolted route left of the bolted corner system /small dihedral of Show Me the Muffin.

4 bolts. Quick clips.

climbs.name: Cascading Failure
climbs.fa: F. Corbett, E. Sloan, F. Côté May 2021

content.description:
Stick clip the first bolt immediately left of Hole in my Pocket. Make hard moves off the ground into some moderate climbing until you reach the third bolt. Move a little left and pull a technical crux. Continue up a tough gear-protected face split by horizontals to the anchor. Gear is bomber but tricky to place and a little bit runout. Bring multiple BD .3s and .4s.



2nd line on the face right of the corner/roofs of Aventure Pédestre. (Between Hole in my Pocket and Be Still my Bleeding Heart) 


3 bolts, small/medium cams

Fun movement for the first few bolts will take you to the crux.  Getting the beta right is key to making it past the crux and onto the easier terrain above.



Start below the cluster of boulders that make up "The Playa" area.  Look for an obvious ramp just left of the second bolt.

6 bolts, single rack from .2 to 1.  Rap Rings.

climbs.name: The Dire Wolf
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Caleb Mazurkiewicz October 2021

content.description:
Start just left of Steal Your Face on large features. Move up the bolt protected face with a couple of optional gear placements. Clip one more bolt before moving into the gear protected crux. Continue to the top of the wall. Gear: .2 through #1 BD cams and 2 medium sized nuts (#4 and 5 DMM). 



Left end of Upper Tier

Standard rack (see above for details). 3 bolts. Tree anchor.

I didn’t name it! Tough start leads to fun climbing to the top.



Extreme right end of Upper Tier in front of a large maple.

1 bolt, trad gear up to #3 and quick-clip anchor

Pull up and mantle on a small ledge. Step left into the corner. Climb the corner and roof and continue up the face above.

Starts near a tree and just right of a right facing corner.

5 bolts, gear up to BD #3. Quick-clip anchors.

Start slightly right of the first bolt on decent holds. Pull up and follow a left-angling diagonal seam to better holds. Continue past an overlap and up a nice face with horizontal slots.

Optional finger sized gear.



Far right side of Upper Tier, right of "the Playa" area. The route starts just right of a large tree growing very close to the base of the cliff. Look for black hangers.

3 bolts. optional finger sized gear. rap rings.

For years, every time I hiked on the Gollum Loop trail I would stop and look at the features on this short wall. 

Finally the inspiration to put it up came. It’s all in the name!



Extreme right of Upper Tier where the Gollum’s Loop Trail starts/ends.

All gear.

Interesting climbing with limited and tricky gear will bring you to the first bolt.  A few easy moves to get up to the second and then the fun begins.  Climbing eases off again once you get to the third bolt.



Found in the middle of the upper tier.  Look for a very high bolt behind a large tree.

Single Rack, 3 bolts, Rap Rings

Climb up past some pockets and continue up the face past 2 bolts. Follow vertical cracks staying left of the corner to the right. Finish up a short squeeze chimney formed by the left side of a large block at the top of the cliff.



Just left of the dihedral of Cherry Garcia

2 bolts, single rack down to .2 BD. Rap rings

Climb the arête just right of the large roofs of Aventure Pédestre. Top out to a tree anchor.



Just right of Aventure Pédestre roofs.

Trad, Tree anchor

Climb up into a nice crack/flake on the left side of the wall to a stance and up a final corner.



At the far right of Upper Tier, where the Gollum's Loop Trail heads uphill, take a short trail down hill to a separate cliff. This is the leftmost route on that cliff.

standard rack. quick clips.

Very technical climbing on dark rock. Follow a few bolts up then make difficult moves up and left to another bolt. Gain a good stance below a small roof. A tricky crux pulling the roof and up to the last bolt then easy climbing to the anchor.

Find the start of the Waltz. This is the second line of bolts right of the Waltz
bolts. rap ring anchor

Get established on the face and move up to a bolt. Continue face climbing to a second bolt. Angle up and slightly left to a good jug. Continue up, eventually moving left into a right-facing ramp. Skirt around the roof and up a few easy moves to the top.



Third route right of the Waltz and the last route before the "Evil" area of chossy rock.

3 bolts, a few finger to medium cams.

climbs.name: Le Miel est plus Doux que le Sang

content.description:
Climb the bolted face past a low crux. Continue up the technical face, saving some energy for the short overhang. Pull left past this overhang then trend up and left to join the last 15ft of the Waltz.

A ways right of where the approach meets the cliff. Look for the bolted face right of the Waltz.
bolted cruxes. a few pieces. tree anchor

Stick clip then climb directly up the extremely thin face/slab. Resist the temptation to bail right on easier terrain. After the last bolt, adventure climb up easy 5th class to some trees.

Left of the obvious roofs of Aventure Pédestre.
3 bolts, single rack

Step a few feet up and onto the ramp and climb the beautiful face. A few crimpy sequences separated by good holds.

Near the far right end of the Upper Tier is an open rocky area which gets a lot of sun. In front of this is the start of a large ramp leading up and left. Monsieur Torpedo starts at the base of this ramp.

bolts + quick-clip anchors.

Climb up the face to a left leaning ramp feature. Most people place a mid-sized cam in this area. Step up and left to stand on top of the ramp feature and clip the next bolt. A brief crux leads to easier climbing.

The optional piece can easily be skipped as it is on the easiest climbing and the next bolt is within reach before making any hard moves.

Near the far right end of the Upper Tier is an open rocky area which gets a lot of sun. In front of this is the start of a large ramp leading up and left. Most Unprecedented starts just right of the base of the ramp
bolts. optional mid sized cam.

Underrated route! Climb the face with the lone bolt, followed by tricky yet solid gear placements.



20ft down and right of the cluster of boulders

1 bolt, trad gear and a bolted anchor.

A cryptic new sport route at the Upper Tier. Once the crux is solved, a jolly balade awaits.



Down and right of the Monsieur Torpedo clusters.

Bolts and quick-clip anchor.

Climb the line of bolts in the middle of the face. Interesting and technical movement.



Where the Gollum's Loop trail heads uphill at the far right of the Upper Tier, head down a short distance to a separate cliff face. This route is the bolted line in the middle of the face.

5 bolts, quick clips

Follow bolts up a black, very technical face to questionable rock and a good stance below the roof. Good gear in a crack that splits the roof and face above. Pull the roof and continue past one more bolt on the face above.

To the right of a scary looking corner (La Peur 5.10 R) and directly in front of a tree.
4 bolts, small to medium cams. rap ring anchor

climbs.name: Réchauffement
climbs.fa: F. Bérubé, M. Thérault, L. Gallant

content.description:
Climb through some questionable rock quality to reach the first bolt.  Pull an awkward sequence to move out left.  From here keep looking for the somewhat weirdly placed bolts (rock quality determined their placement).

This climbs starts on the right side of a small arch.  If you look up and see bolts in a bit of zig zag you are probably in the right spot.
7 bolts to an anchor.

Almost a sport route. Climb the ramp up and right and follow the corner/small dihedral system.



Maybe approximately 30m left of where the approach trail meets the cliff. Look for a small corner system with 3 bolts.

3 bolts, mid sized cam, rap rings.

A pleasant climb up the blocky face to a small roof split by a crack.



5 bolts, medium - small gear for the crack pulling the roof. bolted anchor.

Tricky face climbing past some gear and three bolts leads to a good flake / small ramp where the climbing eases.



Right side of Upper Tier, starting just left of a tree stump at the base of the cliff.

3 bolts, finger sized gear, rap rings

Climb up the face to a small roof. Pull the roof on good holds and continue to the top.

Second route at the left of the Upper Tier. Just right of Witches, and left of a tree.
5 bolts, single rack

Climb up a detached block and step left onto the face just left of the arete. Climb past 2 bolts to the roof. Plug a medium cam in a horizontal, pull the roof, step left and climb the bolted face above.

Shares a start with the Waltz. A short ways right of where the approach trail meets the wall.
Bolts, one mid-sized cam for the horizontal. bolted anchor

Pretty terrible, but not awful. Scramble up the obvious left trending corner/forest just left of The Town Bicycle. Make some surprisingly fun layback moves to a tree close to the top of the wall. Worth doing if you've ticked off the vast majority of The Upper Tier.



Corner at the right end the upper tier

rack to #2 BD, tree anchor

Climb up the technical face. Move slightly left, pull the roof and continue straight up the upper face. After the bolt protecting the roof, there is an optional medium cam placement.

Pretty much directly where the approach trail meets the Upper Tier. Just right of Rock Jock and left of a large tree.
6 bolts. optional medium cam. bolted anchor

Scramble partway up the ramp and climb the leftmost bolted route on this face.

Near the far right end of the Upper Tier is an open rocky area which gets a lot of sun. In front of this is the start of a large ramp leading up and left. The Town Bicycle starts partway up this ramp.
bolts, a couple finger to hand sized cams

Climb up onto a detached block then step left to climb the face left of the arete. Climb this face past 2 bolts to the roof. Step right and climb a beautiful right-angling right-facing dihedral to the top.
Crux is the bolted face, but the nicest climbing is in the dihedral.

A short ways right of where the approach trail meets the cliff. Shares a start with the Tango.
2 bolts, standard rack. Tree anchor

This is a surprisingly tricky route with the crux coming just before the small roof. 

This route is located at the far left of the Upper Tier.  Look for a small roof part way up.
Bolts and a single rack.

Almost a sport route. Fun crimps up the face past 3 bolts then zig-zag up the wall above. 



The second bolted route left of the corner system of Show Me the Muffin.

3 bolts, bring BD .2 - .5 for the top. rap rings

This is the furthest crag from the parking.  The Upper Tier has a little bit of everything with trad, sport, and mixed lines.  Because it is a bit of a hike it sees less traffic than some other walls at Cochrane Lane, but that doesn't mean the climbing isn't superb.  Like most of New Brunswick you may want to bring a brush in case you run into a little moss, but the rock quality is generally really good at the Upper Tier.
